Finding B: Rather, spanking predicted increases in children\'s aggression over and above initial levels.
Finding C: Sociosexuality significantly predicted casual sex engagement after controlling for demographics, OR ¼ 2.06 [1.70, 2.49], p < .001; the interaction with gender was not significant, OR ¼ 1.13 [0.93, 1.36].
Finding D: We note that the causal relations between sleep and depression is an important topic that deserves much further investigation.

Psychology_351_p$Psychology_39_r$Psychol.text:
Finding A: Although the development of an adaptive strategies questionnaire to determine the extent of engagement in adaptive strategies and the relationship of adaptive strategies to remaining HIV negative over time was the end-goal of our study, we also see applicability of our qualitative findings to the development of a risk reduction intervention.
Finding B: / no comments While it is known that the incidence and outward symptoms of schizophrenia are strongly influenced by ethnic factorsaEUR"for instance, patients from Asian ethnicities are more likely to experience visual hallucinations, whereas patients from western cultures and Caucasian ethnicities are more likely to suffer from auditory hallucinationsaEUR"it was unclear if brain deficits would differ amongst suffers from various ethnic backgrounds.
Finding C: Compared with the offspring of mothers aged 25 to 29 years, the offspring of mothers aged 12 to 19 years had a 51% increased risk of having a mental disorder (IRR, 1.51 [95% CI, 1.48-1.54]).
Finding D: Conclusions: The findings suggest that gender differences in the application of intoxication terms are other-directed as well as self-directed and that intoxication language can inform gender-specific prevention and intervention efforts targeting problematic alcohol use among college students.
Psychology_351_p$Psychology_39_r$Psychol.displayed_text:
Finding A: Although the development of an adaptive strategies questionnaire to determine the extent of engagement in adaptive strategies and the relationship of adaptive strategies to remaining HIV negative over time was the end-goal of our study, we also see applicability of our qualitative findings to the development of a risk reduction intervention.
Finding B: / no comments While it is known that the incidence and outward symptoms of schizophrenia are strongly influenced by ethnic factorsaEUR"for instance, patients from Asian ethnicities are more likely to experience visual hallucinations, whereas patients from western cultures and Caucasian ethnicities are more likely to suffer from auditory hallucinationsaEUR"it was unclear if brain deficits would differ amongst suffers from various ethnic backgrounds.
Finding C: Compared with the offspring of mothers aged 25 to 29 years, the offspring of mothers aged 12 to 19 years had a 51% increased risk of having a mental disorder (IRR, 1.51 [95% CI, 1.48-1.54]).
Finding D: Conclusions: The findings suggest that gender differences in the application of intoxication terms are other-directed as well as self-directed and that intoxication language can inform gender-specific prevention and intervention efforts targeting problematic alcohol use among college students.
